item.title: Sexual Assault of Migrants in Panama Rises to Level Rarely Seen Outside War
item.description: The New York Times interviewed more than 70 people who said they had been victims of armed robbery. Fourteen were women who said they had suffered sexual violence.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz and Federico Rios
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times

item.title: Netanyahu Faces Pressure at Home and Abroad, From Foes and Friends
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has the challenge of trying to defeat Hamas while preserving both his government and Israel’s international alliances.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd, Victoria Kim and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Leo Correa
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has come under sharper criticism from allies including the United States.

item.title: Iran Says 17-Hour Battle With Separatists Leaves 28 Dead in 2 Cities
item.description: Jaish al-Adl, an ethnic Baluch group designated by the United States as a terrorist organization, claimed responsibility for the attacks.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Leily Nikounazar
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Iranians breaking their fast on Wednesday during Ramadan in Tehran near a giant banner of Gen. Mohammad Reza Zahedi, who was killed on Monday in an Israeli airstrike in Syria.

item.title: NATO Wants to Show Support for Ukraine, but Only So Much
item.description: Admitting Kyiv is a nonstarter as long as the war with Russia is raging. But the member nations want to show they are supporting Ukraine “for the long haul.”
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers of the 32nd Mechanized Brigade in the Kharkiv region of Ukraine on Monday. Ukraine hopes for a formal invitation to join NATO.

item.title: Israeli Strikes in Damascus and Gaza Show Strengths and Limits of Accuracy
item.description: In an airstrike on Monday in Damascus, Israel’s military displayed pinpoint precision. Hours later in Gaza, that same military killed seven aid workers.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Louai Beshara/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An airstrike by the Israeli military on an Iranian embassy complex in Damascus killed Iranian intelligence officers and Palestinian militants but not a single civilian, Iranian officials said.

item.title: In Moscow Attack, a Handful of Suspects but a Million Tajiks Under Suspicion
item.description: The main suspects in a deadly assault near Moscow were from Tajikistan. Now many other Tajiks, who fill jobs in Russia’s wartime economy, are being deported and harassed.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Valeriya Safronova and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: A market in the suburbs of Moscow, where many people from Central Asian countries, such as Tajikistan, work.

item.title: Why Taiwan Was So Prepared for a Powerful Earthquake
item.description: Decades of learning from disasters, tightening building codes and increasing public awareness may have helped its people better weather strong quakes.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Meaghan Tobin, Siyi Zhao and Lam Yik Fei
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times

item.title: Finland School Shooting’s Motive Was Bullying, Police Say
item.description: The police said the motive emerged during interviews with the student, who after the shooting also threatened students heading to another school.
item.dc:creator: Johanna Lemola and Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Jussi Nukari/Lehtikuva, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A flag at half-staff on the grounds of the school in Vantaa, Finland, on Wednesday.

item.title: Kuwaitis Vote With Hope for Change Amid Political Turmoil
item.description: With a new ruler in charge, the oil-rich emirate is electing a new Parliament for the fourth time in four years while grappling with political turmoil.
item.dc:creator: Yasmena Almulla and Vivian Nereim
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Sheikh Mishal Al Ahmed Al Sabah
item.media:credit: Jaber Abdulkhaleg/Associated Press
item.media:description: With a portrait of Kuwait’s ruler, Sheikh Mishal Al Ahmed Al Sabah, looming overhead, Kuwaitis voted for Parliament in Al Riqqa district on Thursday.

item.title: Denmark Closes Shipping Lane Over Risk of Accidental Missile Launch
item.description: The military said the missile malfunctioned during a test aboard a warship, and there was a possibility it could fly a short distance, but no risk of the warhead exploding.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses and Maya Tekeli
item.media:credit: Lars Laursen/Ritzau Scanpix, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Great Belt Bridge in Denmark on July 2022.

item.title: Bologna Looks to the Leaning Tower of Pisa for Tips to Stop Garisenda’s Tilt
item.description: Bologna is looking to Pisa, home of the most famous leaning tower, for help keeping its own tipping tower upright.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Susan Wright for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Matteo Lepore of Bologna, Italy, announced that the city would adopt a system successfully used to save the Tower of Pisa for the Garisenda Tower, to the left of the taller structure.

item.title: Venice to Charge Day Trippers an Entry Fee to Discourage Overcrowding
item.description: Starting this month, tourists intending to visit the city on busy dates will be required to register on a website, and those coming for a single day will have to pay a little over $5.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Rialto Bridge in central Venice in 2022.

item.title: Taiwan’s 7.4-Magnitude Earthquake Kills 9 and Injures Over 1000
item.description: The magnitude-7.4 quake was followed by more than 200 aftershocks. Dozens of people were trapped. Two buildings in the city of Hualien teetered perilously.
item.dc:creator: Meaghan Tobin, Victoria Kim, Chris Buckley, Mike Ives, Siyi Zhao and John Yoon
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times

item.title: South Korea’s Doctors’ Walkout Spurs Thousands of Complaints
item.description: Thousands of interns and residents who stopped working in February are testing the public’s high regard for physicians. But there is also anger at the government.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Anthony Wallace/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Many young doctors at South Korean hospitals stopped working weeks ago, to protest the government’s plan to enroll more students in medical schools.

item.title: In Australia, a Nation’s Banh Mi Love Affair
item.description: “We’ll make the best of it here. And they can call it a pork roll.”
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Manan Vatsyayana/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Banh mi.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: The Times’s Jerusalem bureau chief on six months of war between Israel and Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:credit: Fatima Shbair/Associated Press
item.media:description: Mourning relatives killed during strikes in Rafah.

item.title: Israel Agrees to Open Erez Crossing for Gaza Aid After Biden Pressure, U.S. Says
item.description: Israel has come under rising pressure from U.S. officials and humanitarian agencies to allow more aid into Gaza, amid warnings that famine is looming.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd and Erica L. Green
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers at the Erez border crossing in December.

item.title: Richard Benedick, Negotiator of Landmark Ozone Treaty, Dies at 88
item.description: He played a key role in securing the Montreal Protocol, an international environmental pact to protect the ozone layer by reducing the use of certain chemicals.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel

item.title: Friday Briefing: Six Months of the Israel-Hamas War
item.description: Also, the rise of “carefluencers.”
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Ahmad Hasaballah/Getty Images
item.media:description: Praying during Ramadan at a ruined mosque in Rafah, Gaza.

item.title: Eyeglasses Improve Income as Well as Sight, Study Shows
item.description: A study found that when farsighted workers in Bangladesh were given free reading glasses, they earned 33 percent more than those who had not.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: According to the W.H.O., the lack of access to corrective eyewear inhibits learning among students, increases the likelihood of traffic accidents and forces middle-age factory workers and farmers to prematurely leave the work force.

item.title: Israeli Military Cancels Leave for Combat Units After Airstrike in Syria
item.description: Though no reason was given for the moves, Israeli newspapers said they came amid fears of an increased threat from Iran after an Israeli strike in Syria.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers in Gaza during a media tour conducted by the Israeli forces on Sunday.

item.title: Israel to Add Gaza Aid Routes After Biden’s Tense Call With Netanyahu
item.description: The president denounced the killing of seven humanitarian workers in a tense call with Israel’s prime minister. Within hours, Israel agreed to increase aid deliveries.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: During a 30-minute call with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, President Biden went further than ever in pressing for change in the military operation.

item.title: How an Editor’s Note on Kate Middleton’s Video Fueled Conspiracy Theories
item.description: A routine Getty Images caption beside the Princess of Wales’s cancer announcement has fanned disinformation about her. Researchers say there is no evidence that the video is fake.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: BBC Studios/Handout, via Reuters
item.media:description: In a prerecorded video released on March 22 by the palace, Catherine, Princess of Wales, announced she had cancer.

item.title: A Tantalizing ‘Hint’ That Astronomers Got Dark Energy All Wrong
item.description: Scientists may have discovered a major flaw in their understanding of that mysterious cosmic force. That could be good news for the fate of the universe.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye

item.title: World Central Kitchen Demands an Independent Investigation Into Israeli Strike
item.description: The Israeli military, which has accepted responsibility for the strike, has started looking into the killings of seven aid workers. But the disaster relief organization said that was not enough.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: United Nations staff members inspecting one of the destroyed vehicles used by World Central Kitchen.

item.title: Lawyers and Retired Judges Call On U.K. Government to End Arms Sales to Israel
item.description: The government is coming under more pressure to suspend arms sales to Israel after the strike on a convoy in Gaza that killed seven aid workers, including three Britons.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Benjamin Cremel/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A pro-Palestinian protest in Trafalgar Square in London last week.

item.title: Panama’s 2024 Election: What to Know
item.description: Political crisis has embroiled Panama’s May 5 presidential election, exacerbating uncertainty in a country dealing with drought and fallout from widespread protests.
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.media:credit: Martin Bernetti/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Another A.I. Target: Food Waste
item.description: Artificial intelligence is peering into restaurant garbage pails and crunching grocery-store data to try to figure out how to send less uneaten food into dumpsters.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: U.S. Defense Secretary Denounces Israel’s Strike on Aid Workers in Gaza
item.description: A bristling phone call reflected a shift in Lloyd J. Austin III’s tone toward his Israeli counterpart as he stressed the need for better protection of aid workers.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Mohammed Saber/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A destroyed car used by World Central Kitchen after an Israeli strike in Gaza this week. Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III upbraided his Israeli counterpart, Yoav Gallant, over the deadly attack.

item.title: Biden and Netanyahu speak as a senior official says the president’s anger with Israel has hit a peak.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden said that he was “outraged and heartbroken” by the deaths of seven workers from the charity World Central Kitchen.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: Ukraine expands its draft.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers training in the country’s Donetsk region on Monday.

item.title: How a Violin Maker’s Dreams Came True in Cremona, Italy
item.description: As a teenager in South Korea, Ayoung An decided to become a violin maker. Her journey eventually took her to Cremona, Italy, a famed hub for masters like Antonio Stradivari.
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova and Sasha Arutyunova
item.media:credit: Sasha Arutyunova for The New York Times

item.title: Canadian Politicians Were Targeted by China in 2021, Report Says
item.description: Lawmakers testified at a public hearing on foreign interference that they had been caught in China’s cross hairs after criticizing it over human rights.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Tingshu Wang/Reuters
item.media:description: Since President Xi Jinping’s rise to power, China has stepped up efforts to sway elections in Canada and other countries, according to intelligence officials, academics and members of the diaspora.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Ukraine Lowers the Draft Age
item.description: Also, dozens remain trapped after the earthquake in Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: New Ukrainian recruits training last year.

item.title: World Central Kitchen Workers Delivered Aid. Then Their Convoy Was Hit.
item.description: The deaths of World Central Kitchen workers pushed the number of aid employees killed during the war in Gaza to at least 196, according to the U.N. secretary general, António Guterres.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd, Abu Bakr Bashir, Riley Mellen, Aaron Boxerman and Aric Toler
item.media:credit: Said Khatib/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Relatives and friends praying near the body of a staff member of World Central Kitchen in Rafah, Gaza, on Tuesday.

item.title: Ex-Leader of South Africa Legislature Is Arrested on Corruption Charges
item.description: The legal problems of Nosiviwe Mapisa-Nqakula expose the governing African National Congress to one of its biggest weaknesses — corruption allegations — before a crucial national election.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:credit: Phill Magakoe/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Nosiviwe Mapisa-Nqakula in court in Pretoria, South Africa, on Thursday. She stepped down as speaker of the country’s National Assembly this week.

item.title: IDF Says UN Observers in Lebanon Were Wounded by Hezbollah Explosive
item.description: A spokesman for the Israeli military said the blast was caused “by an explosive previously installed there by Hezbollah,” a Lebanese militia and political movement.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Hassan Ammar/Associated Press
item.media:description: A station of the U.N. peacekeeping forces in Lebanon, in Markaba, near the border with Israel, last year.

item.title: NATO Weighs Taking Over Ukraine Defense Contact Group
item.description: The proposal faces several obstacles, including whether all members would agree to the changes. But the alliance is worried about wavering American support for Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers prepared to move a howitzer in the Kharkiv region of the country this week.

item.title: Inflation Cools in Eurozone, Nearing Central Bank’s Target
item.description: Prices in the countries that use the euro rose 2.4 percent in the year through March, coming closer to the European Central Bank’s 2 percent inflation target.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy

item.title: What We Know About the 7.4-Magnitude Earthquake in Taiwan
item.description: The quake set off aftershocks and damaged dozens of buildings, killing nine people and leaving many injured or trapped.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Taiwan’s Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A collapsed brick wall in a house after the earthquake in Taipei.

item.title: Zelensky Lowers Draft Age for Ukraine’s Depleted Army
item.description: The idea of requiring more men to join the fight against Russia’s invasion has become toxic, but Russia is not relenting in its assault.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers training in the country’s Donetsk region on Monday.

item.title: How Soccer Learned to Embrace Ramadan: From Faked Injuries to Bespoke Diets
item.description: In competitions like the Premier League, Muslim pros who once faced pressure to avoid daily fasts during the monthlong holiday now benefit from custom diets and in-game breaks.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:credit: George Wood/Getty Images
item.media:description: Everton’s Muslim players broke their fast during a prearranged pause in their Premier League match at Newcastle on Tuesday.

item.title: Ugandan Court Upholds Draconian Anti-Gay Law
item.description: The law, which includes the death penalty as a punishment in some cases, has been strongly condemned, including by the United States.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Hajarah Nalwadda/Associated Press
item.media:description: The five-judge panel of Uganda’s Constitutional Court at a hearing in Kampala, the capital, on Wednesday. “The upshot of our judgment is that this petition substantially fails,” one judge said.

item.title: Hualien, on Taiwan’s Coast, Is Prone to Earthquakes
item.description: The area, known for a famous gorge and aquamarine waters, sits on several active faults.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Ashley Pon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rice fields in Hualien County in 2021. The scenic area is one of the most sparsely populated parts of Taiwan.

item.title: The Taiwan Earthquake’s Aftermath in Photos
item.description: See scenes from around the island.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: A road in Taroko National Park was closed because of a landslide in Hualien, Taiwan, on Thursday.

item.title: Taiwan Quake Damages Buildings and a Highway in Hualien
item.description: Rescue efforts in the city were centered on two buildings, one of which appeared near collapse. Some roads to the region were cut off.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Paul Mozur, Meaghan Tobin and John Yoon
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: A leaning building in Hualien, a city on the eastern coast of Taiwan, on Wednesday.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Seven aid workers killed in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A car used by World Central Kitchen was hit by an Israeli strike in Deir al Balah, Gaza.

item.title: ‘The Russian Language Is Everywhere Again’: Exiles Cause Unease in Lithuania
item.description: An influx of exiled Russian activists and refugees from Ukraine and Belarus is stirring fears in a country that fought to preserve its language and culture under Soviet occupation.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Alina Lobzina and Tomas Dapkus
item.media:credit: Andrej Vasilenko for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vilnius has become a center of the Russian political opposition.

item.title: Inside an English Village Scarred by a High-Speed Railway, HS2
item.description: When Britain cut back a planned high-speed rail line, some residents on the route were pleased. They’re less delighted with what happened next.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: More than 50 homes in the area have stood empty for two years or more, campaigners say — years during which HS2’s ambitions shrank markedly.

item.title: A Look at Taiwan’s Strongest Earthquakes
item.description: Earthquakes of similar intensity to the one that hit the island on Wednesday have caused large-scale death and destruction.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Tyrone Siu/Reuters
item.media:description: A 17-story apartment building that collapsed after an earthquake in Tainan, Taiwan, in 2016.

item.title: U.S. Intelligence Warning to Moscow Named Specific Target of Attack
item.description: The C.I.A. told Russia that Islamic State terrorists were plotting an attack on Crocus City Hall, a concert venue.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Some Western officials have said that when an attack failed to materialize immediately after a U.S. warning, Russia appeared to have lowered its guard.

item.title: Biden Outraged After Israel Claims Attack on Aid Workers Was a Mistake
item.description: In a sharply worded statement, Mr. Biden said that Israel had not done enough to protect civilians and noted that the deaths were not a “stand-alone incident.”
item.dc:creator: Ben Shpigel, Cassandra Vinograd and Erica L. Green
item.media:credit: Said Khatib/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The funeral of Saif Abu Taha, a 26-year-old Gazan who worked as a driver and translator for World Central Kitchen, in Rafah on Tuesday.

item.title: What We Know About the Iranian Commanders Killed by Israel in Syria
item.description: The leaders included Gen. Mohammad Reza Zahedi, the senior most leader in Iran’s armed forces assassinated since Qassim Suleimani was killed in 2020.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Iranians Tuesday demonstrated against the Israeli strike that killed Iranian commanders in Damascus, Syria.

item.title: Canadian Lawmaker Says China Had Chinese Students Vote for Him
item.description: Han Dong, a member of Parliament who is accused of benefiting from the Chinese government’s help, testified at a public hearing on foreign interference.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Rene Johnston/Toronto Star, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Han Dong’s testimony was part of an ongoing federal inquiry into foreign meddling in Canada’s political system, especially the general elections of 2019 and 2021.

item.title: Protest Outside Netanyahu’s Home Turns Into ‘Riot,’ Israeli Police Say
item.description: Antigovernment demonstrators took to the streets for the third night in a row to call for early elections.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Ohad Zwigenberg/Associated Press
item.media:description: Some demonstrators tried to break through barriers near Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s house, the police said.

item.title: 7 Aid Workers Killed in Gaza Were Known for a Passion for Helping Others
item.description: Gaza has been the deadliest place for aid workers since the Oct. 7 attacks.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Said Khatib/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Relatives and friends mourn the death of Saif Abu Taha, one of the seven workers with World Central Kitchen who was killed in Gaza when an aid convoy was fired on Monday night.
